page.title: 05MEMORIES OF SILK WILLOUGHBY
page.content: Alice Brown remembers that{Silk {Willoughby}was once owned by the Earl of Dysart, but was sold in the early 1920's.{Farm workers}had to rise early to feed the stock. One could hear the clip clop of horses going down the quiet country lanes to pull the ploughs. Nearly every household would have a pigsty in the yard and would keep at least one pig, which would be slaughtered at Christmas time. She remembers the{village shop, which closed in l968, and saw the widening of School Lane and Gorse Lane. Mrs Brown, who has lived in {Silk Willoughby}since 1918, misses the clang of the blacksmith's hammer, the noise of the cows in the fields and the horses cantering to and fro bringing the harvest grain into the farmyards. These things are lost to us now.
